Forces Europe to complete Nordstream II, Ukraine loses transit fees for the gas, and Europe has an energy crisis until Nordstream is done.

@IAmNickDodson I think it's mostly a question of knowing the funds are there and knowing how to bridge them (much more complex than a simple transfer).

I generally have pretty low expectations for governments + technology.

Challenges of a multi-chain world:

In addition to Ethereum, people are sending donations to the Ukrainian government on BSC, Arbitrum, Polygon and more.

I hope the government knows how to bridge.

RT @hudsonjameson: One of the issues with critiques on proof-of-stake is that many of the live PoS protocols have on-chain governance with‚Ä¶
@owocki @svantetobias The GTC token already has checkpoints built in, so it should be pretty easy to fork the token (similar to @thegrifft's MiniMe token)
@arjunbhuptani @FrancescoRenziA @ASvanevik @ConnextNetwork @nomadxyz_ I'm not familiar with them, sounds like I need to read up on it!

@FrancescoRenziA @arjunbhuptani @ASvanevik @ConnextNetwork @nomadxyz_ No trust assumptions

For example, bridging between Arbitrum and Optimism can be done trustlessly because they share security

Bridging over IBC has the security of either chain (ether validator set can attack)

Most other bridges rely on multisigs

@jai_prasad17 @ASvanevik Sidechains can't interact with other chains without some trust assumptions

So you _could_ build these applications on other L1s, but I imagine most developers will prefer to depend on a bridge that can't be arbitrarily turned off

@jai_prasad17 @ASvanevik Imagine the core financial apps being deployed to L1, but users interact using L2s

You get composability and shared liquidity, but still low transaction fees.
RT @Jeyffre: Scams like these rely on the fact that we are conditioned to approve ERC 20 tokens before using them. It's such a bad design.‚Ä¶

We're still in the phase of "minimum viable rollup", where rollups are just trying to be as feature-complete as Ethereum.

As the technology matures, we're going to see a lot more experimentation & novel rollup designs.

For a preview, just look at Cosmos Zones & Parachains. https://t.co/WtcM7DWsXe
@LukeWalken @paulemmanuelng @ASvanevik The most interesting cross-chain applications require ZK rollups (for the fast L1 settlement), and general-purpose ZKRs are basically not ready yet

@FrancescoRenziA @ASvanevik @ConnextNetwork @nomadxyz_ Feels pretty early, most L2s are focused on just being independent chains, and most bridges are focused on token transfers

The x-chain projects I'm interested in are Tati/@transmissions11's Nova,  @StarkWareLtd's DeFi pooling, and the similar work from @aztecnetwork

@10xray @safetyth1rd Uniswap released a contract for liquidity mining for V3, but it's had minimal adoption.

However, me and the L222 gang (led by @litocoen) built an updated version, which just finished audit. Hopefully, will bring more farming to V3.

@PortunusOG @0xRudi @kelvinfichter @CryptoFeesInfo Yes, the efficiency depends on the implementation

Arbitrum/Optimism post full L1-sized calldata (although they're both adding compression), while Fuel will have a very efficient amount of calldata to post. And some ZKRs don't post calls at all, just state diffs

@RyanBerckmans @kluza @CryptoFeesInfo Interesting tiers:

- Ethereum L1
- Full rollups
- Rollups with independent, decentralized data availability (Celestia)
- Rollups with centralized data availability (validium)
- Sidechains/alt-L1s
- BSC
@0xBrigandine @CryptoFeesInfo Which colors? The chart?
@berteotti_ https://t.co/AkghgRrVLR
@stonecoldpat0 @kelvinfichter @CryptoFeesInfo Good idea, I'll look into that

@0xRudi @kelvinfichter @CryptoFeesInfo Hmm I like it, a little long, what about "how much are rollups paying for block space?"

Or a 2 liner:
"Rollups need to buy block space.
How much are they spending?"
@stonecoldpat0 @kelvinfichter @CryptoFeesInfo Pie chart comparing L2s against each-other, or pie chart as a percent of total fees?
@lucie_xyz I wasn't digging the camera at first, but I actually think it's pretty fitting
@kelvinfichter @CryptoFeesInfo Ya that's definitely the message it should express, but the phrasing still feels a little off to me. I'll think it over a bit...

@stonecoldpat0 @kelvinfichter @CryptoFeesInfo Yep, I can see how this chart can be viewed as "which rollup is more secure", when the intention was more "look at these 'customers' of Ethereum blockspace". I agree that it should make it clear that _all_ of these chains are equally secure**.

RT @RyanSAdams: "Users don't care about decentralization" is such a myopic take.

Future blockchain users aren't people...they're chains.‚Ä¶

@kelvinfichter @CryptoFeesInfo I've never been a fan of "average cost per tx" as a metric, since transactions are not equal. You can't really compare at tx that sends ETH, to a complex flashloan DEX arbitrage tx.
@kelvinfichter @CryptoFeesInfo Maybe "How much are rollups paying for Ethereum's security" needs to be re-phrased, do you have any suggestions?

@stonecoldpat0 @kelvinfichter @CryptoFeesInfo > this may encourage projects "not to optimise gas costs" to look better

Couldn't you say the same thing about https://t.co/DwlPJ2XL6n?
One interesting way to frame this metric: compare L2s, which collect fees and pay Ethereum for security, vs L1s paying for security with issuance (https://t.co/pomjEXbWq2)
@KyleReidhead @CryptoFeesInfo Added! https://t.co/Vtse6B0qsn

Just pushed a cool update to https://t.co/ve9FiASLSc!

While @CryptoFeesInfo tracks the amount users pay to rollups, this new dashboard how much fees L2s pay to L1.

We all know that L2 rollups need to pay Ethereum for security, and this metric is a good measure of that. https://t.co/qb2Z8PKADn
